citations.narrative:
A double-sided gate that is part of the perimeter fence near the haybarn has developed gaps between the gates;
additionally, the barbed wire strands along the top of the right gate are damaged and hanging downward on the outside,
resulting in the gate being ~88" in height, short of the 96" (eight feet) required for the species at the facility. Several
sections of the perimeter fence on the side bordering the areas near the caracal enclosure have barbed wire strands at
the top that are bent, broken or disrupted by trees, resulting in damage and causing the fence to be shorter than the
required eight feet in height.
Perimeter fences that are in poor repair or which are unstable, cannot serve as effective secondary containment for the
animals at the zoo and can be an entry point for unauthorized persons or predators that could cause harm to the animals.
The licensee must ensure that all perimeter fences at the facility are of adequate height and in good repair to maintain
their strength and integrity. The perimeter fence must be a minimum of three feet away from any primary enclosures and
constructed so that it protects the animals by restricting entry of outside animals and preventing unauthorized persons
from going through it, or under it, or having contact with the animals in the facility.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection, an unsexed, adult Jandaya parakeet ("Junior") and an unsexed, adult scarlet macaw ("Rambo")
are housed in a manner that individually isolates them, preventing them from being able to hear and see each other or
other birds of the same or compatible species. The facility's plan for environmental enhancement of avian species states
that, when birds are housed individually in this manner, they will receive increased enrichment and the facility will provide
an expected length of time that the animal(s) will experience this type of housing. However, these two birds were not
receiving additional enrichment and the facility did not have a plan or timeframe for rectifying these isolating housing
conditions.
Birds requiring special attention include individually housed social species of birds that are unable to see and hear birds of
their own or compatible species. Failure to provide additional environmental enhancement for isolated birds that are
intelligent and social species may lead to their poor psychological health and welfare. The licensee must ensure that such
birds are provided special attention regarding enhancement of their environment, based on the needs of the individual
species and/or individual bird and in accordance with the environmental enhancement plan and instructions approved by
the attending veterinarian.
TO BE CORRECTED BY 05 DECEMBER 2023

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
In the enclosure housing two, adult female emu, there is a leaking water pipe causing water to accumulate to a depth of
several inches over an area of ~12 square feet.
Standing water can become stagnant, encourage the growth of harmful microbes and provide a breeding ground for pests
that can spread disease. The licensee must ensure that standing water, except for such water in pools or other aquatic
areas (e.g., ponds, waterfalls, fountains, and other intentional water features), is removed from the primary enclosure.
TO BE CORRECTED BY 05 DECEMBER 2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the zoo director.
n

3.154(c)(4) 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
At the time of inspection, an unsexed, adult Jandaya parakeet ("Junior") and an unsexed, adult scarlet macaw ("Rambo") 
are housed in a manner that individually isolates them, preventing them from being able to hear and see each other or

Birds requiring special attention include individually housed social species of birds that are unable to see and hear birds of 
their own or compatible species. Failure to provide additional environmental enhancement for isolated birds that are 
intelligent and social species may lead to their poor psychological health and welfare. The licensee must ensure that such 
birds are provided special attention regarding enhancement of their environment, based on the needs of the individual 
species and/or individual bird and in accordance with the environmental enhancement plan and instructions approved by

the attending veterinarian. 
TO BE CORRECTED BY 05 DECEMBER 2023 
3.158(a)(1) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
In the enclosure housing two, adult female emu, there is a leaking water pipe causing water to accumulate to a depth of 
several inches over an area of ~12 square feet.  
Standing water can become stagnant, encourage the growth of harmful microbes and provide a breeding ground for pests 
that can spread disease. The licensee must ensure that standing water, except for such water in pools or other aquatic

TO BE CORRECTED BY 05 DECEMBER 2023
